the family and friend of the late lord elgin as to the best mode of give to the world some record of he life and have thus contract a certain responsibility in the work now lay before the public i have consider it my duty to prefix a few word by way of preface to the follow page on lord elgin 's death it be think that a career intimately connect with so many critical point in the history of the british empire and contain in itself so much of intrinsic interest ought not to be leave without a enduring memorial the need of this be the more feel because lord elgin be prevent by the peculiar circumstance of he public course from enjoy the familiar recognition to which he would else have be entitle amongst he contemporary in england ` for ' -lrb- if i may use the word which i have employ on a former occasion -rrb- ` it be one of the sad consequence of a statesman 's life spend like he in the constant service of he country on arduous foreign mission that in he own land in he own circle almost in he own home he place be occupy by other he very face be forget he can maintain no permanent tie with those who rule the opinion or obtain the mastery of the day he have identify himself with no exist party he have make himself feel in none of those domestic and personal struggle which attract the attention and fix the interest of the many who contribute in large measure to form the public opinion of the time for twenty year the few interval of lord elgin 's residence in these island be to be count not by year but by month and the majority of those who might be reckon amongst he friend and acquaintance remember he chiefly as the eager and accomplished oxford student at christ church or at merton ' the material for supply this blank be in some respects abundant besides the official despatch and other communication which have pass between himself and the home government during he successive absence in jamaica canada china and indium he have in the two latter position keep up a constant correspondence almost of the nature of a journal with lady elgin which combine with he reflection on public event the expression of he more personal feeling and thus reveal not only he own genial and affectionate nature but also indicate something of that singularly poetic and philosophic turn of mind that union of grace and power which have he course lain in the more tranquil walk of life would have achieve no mean place amongst english thinker and writer these material he family at my suggestion commit to my friend mr theodore walrond whose sound judgment comprehensive view and official experience be know to many besides myself and who seem not less fit to act as interpreter to the public at large of such a life and character because not have be personally acquaint with lord elgin or connect with any of the public transaction record in the follow page he be able to speak with the sobriety of calm appreciation rather than the warmth of personal attachment in this spirit he kindly undertake in the interval of constant public occupation to select from the vast mass of material place at he disposal such extract as most vividly bring out the main feature of lord elgin 's career add such illustration as could be glean from private or publish document or from the remembrance of friend if the work have unavoidably be delay beyond the expect term yet it be hope that the interest in those great colonial dependency for which lord elgin labor have not diminish with the lapse of year it be believe also that there be no time when it will not be good for he countryman to have bring before they those statesmanlike gift which accomplish the successful accommodation of a more varied series of novel and entangled situation than have perhaps fall to the lot of any other public man within we own memory especially might be name that rare quality of a strong overrule sense of the justice due from man to man from nation to nation that ` combination of speculative and practical ability ' -lrb- so write one who have deep experience of he mind -rrb- ` which peculiarly fit he to solve the problem how the subject race of a civilised empire be to be govern ' that firm courageous and far-sighted confidence in the triumph of those liberal and constitutional principle -lrb- in the best sense of the word -rrb- which have secure the greatness of england be in he judgment also applicable under other form to the difficult circumstance of new country and diverse time ` it be a singular coincidence ' say lord elgin in a speech at benare a few month before he end ` that three successive governors-general of indium should have stand towards each other in the relationship of contemporary friend lord dalhousie when name to the government of indium be the youngest man who have ever be appoint to a situation of such high responsibility and trust lord canning be in the prime of life and i if i be not already on the decline be nearer to the verge of it than either of my contemporary who have precede I when i be leave england for indium lord ellenborough who be now alas the only survive ex-governor-general say to I ` you be not a very old man but depend upon it you will find yourself by far the oldest man in indium ' to that mournful catalogue be add he own name within the brief space of one year and now a fourth not indeed bind to the other by tie of personal or political friendship but like in energetic discharge of he duty and in the prime of usefulness in which he be cut off have fall by a fate yet more untimely these tragical incident invest the high office to which such precious life have be sacrifice with a new and solemn interest there be something especially pathetic when the gallant vessel as it be go down within very sight of the harbor with all its accumulate treasure but no loss more appeal at the moment to the heart of the country no career deserve to be more carefully enshrine in its grateful remembrance arthur p stanley _ -lrb- sidenote : birth and parentage -rrb- jame eighth earl of elgin and twelfth earl of kincardine be bear in london on July 20 1811 he father whose career as ambassador at constantinople be so well know in connection with the ` elgin marble ' be the chief and representative of the ancient norman house whose hero be ` robert the bruce ' from he it may be say that he inherit the genial and playful spirit which give such a charm to he social and parental relation and which help he to elicit from other the knowledge of which he make so much use in the many diverse situation of he after-life he mother lord elgin 's second wife be a daughter of mr oswald of dunnikier in fifeshire she deep piety unite with wide reach of mind and vary culture make she admirably qualify to be the depositary of the ardent thought and aspiration of he boyhood and as he grow up he find a second mother in he elder sister matilda who become the wife of sir john maxwell of pollok to the influence of such a mother and such a sister he probably owe the pliancy and power of sympathy with other for which he be remarkable and which be not often find in character of so tough a fiber to they from he earliest year he confide the outpouring of he deeper religious feeling one expression of such feeling date June 1821 may be worth record as a example of that strong sense of duty and affection towards he brother which begin at that early age mark he whole subsequent career ` be with I this week in my study my amusement in everything when at my lesson may i think only of they play when i play : when dress may i be quick and never put off time and never amuse myself but in playhor oh may i set a good example to nay brother let I not teach they anything that be bad and may they not learn wickedness from see I may i command my temper and passion and give I a better heart for they good ' -lrb- sidenote : school and college -rrb- he learn the rudiment of latin and greek under the careful teaching of a resident tutor mr fergus jardine at the age of fourteen he go to eton and thence in due time to christ church oxford where he find he self among a group of young man destine to distinction in after-life -- lord canning jame ramsay -lrb- afterwards lord dalhousie -rrb- the late duke of newcastle sidney herbert and mr gladstone there be little to record respect this period of he life but a touching interest attach to the following extract from a letter write by he brother sir frederick bruce in November 1865 ` my recollection of elgin 's early life be owe to circumstance almost nothing in the year 1820 he go abroad with my father and mother and be away for two year from that time i recollect nothing until he go to eton and he holiday be then divide between torquay where my eldest brother be and broomhall -lrb- 1 -rrb- and of they my memory have retain nothing but the assistance in he later holiday he use to give I in classical study we be together for about a year and a half at oxford but he be so far advance in he study that we have very little in common to bring we together and i hardly remember any striking fact connect with he except one or two speech at the union club when in eloquence and originality he far outshine he competitor -lrb- 2 -rrb- ' i do not know whether mr welland be still alive : he probably better than anyone could give some sketch of he intellectual growth and of that beautiful trait in he character the devotion and abnegation he show o poor bruce -lrb- 3 -rrb- in he long and painful illness ` he be always reserve about he own feeling and aspiration owe to the shortness of he stay at oxford he have to work very hard and he friend like newcastle and hamilton be man who seek he for the soundness of he judgment which lead they to seek he advice in all matter he always stand to they in the relation of a much older man he have none of the frailty of youth and though very capable of enjoy its diversion life with he from a very early date be sickly o'er with the pale cast of think its practical aspect to he be one of anxiety and difficulty while he intellect be attract to high and abstract speculation and take little interest in the every-day routine which be sufficient occupation for ordinary mind like all man of original mind he live a life apart from he fellow ` he look upon the family estate rather as a trust than as a inheritance -- as far more valuable than money on account of the family tradition and the position which in we state of society be give to a family connect historically with the country elgin feel this deeply and he cling to it in spite of difficulty which would have deter a man of more purely selfish view ' ` it be melancholy to reflect ' add sir f bruce ` how those have disappear who could have fill up this gap in he history ' it be a reflection even more melancholy that the loved and trust brother who share so many of he labor and he aspiration no longer live to write that history and to illustrate in he own person the spirit by which it be animated the sense of the difficulty above refer to strongly impressed he mind even before he go to oxford and lay the foundation of that habit of self-denial in all personal matter which enable he through life to retain a feeling of independence and at the same time to give effect to the prompting of a generous nature ` you tell I ' he write to he father from college ' i coin money i uncoined you last order by put it into the fire have already supply myself ' about the middle of he oxford career a studentship fall vacant which accord to the strange system then prevalent be in the gift of dr bull one of the canon of christ church instead of bestow it as be too commonly do on grounds of private interest dr bull place the valuable prize at the disposal of the dean and censor to be confer on the most worthy of the undergraduate they choice fall on jame bruce in announce this to a member of the bruce family dr bull write : ` dr smith no less than the present college officer assure I that there be no young man of whatever rank who could be more acceptable to the society and none whose appointment as the reward of excellent deportment diligence and right-mindedness would do more good among the young man ' a letter write about this time to he father show that the young student with a sagacity beyond he year discern the germ of a evil which have since grow to a great height and now lie at the root of some of the most troublesome question connect with university education in my own mind i confess i be much of opinion that college be put off in general till too late -lrb- 4 -rrb- and the gain of _ honor _ therefore become too severe to be useful to man who be to enter into profession it be certainly originally intend that the degree which require only a knowledge of the classic should be take at a earlier age in order to admit of a residence after they be take during which the student might devote himself to science or composition and those habit of reflection by which the mind might be form and a practical advantage draw from the store of knowledge already acquire by put they off to so late a age the consequence have be that it have be necessary proportionably to increase the difficulty of they attainment and to mix up in college examination -lrb- which be suppose to depend upon study alone -rrb- essay in many case of a nature that demand the most prolonged and deep reflection the effect of this be evident those who from circumstance have neither opportunity nor leisure thus to reflect must in order to secure they success acquire that kind of superficial information which may enable they to draw sufficiently plausible conclusion upon very slight grounds and -lrb- of -rrb- many who have this _ form _ of knowledge most will eventually be prove -lrb- if this system be carry to a excess -rrb- to have but little of the _ substance _ of it he have mean to read for double honor but illness bring on by over - work oblige he to confine himself to classic all who know oxford be aware that the term ` classic ' as there use embrace not only greek and latin scholarship but also ancient history and philosophy in these latter study the natural taste and previous education of jame bruce lead he to take a special interest and he throw himself into the work in no niggard spirit -lrb- 5 -rrb- at the michaelma examination of 1832 he be place in the first class in classic and common report speak of he as ` the best first of he ` year ' not long afterwards he be elect fellow of merton he appear to have be a candidate also for the eldon scholarship but without success in a contest for a legal prize it be no discredit to be defeat by roundell palmer -lrb- sidenote : taste for philosophy -rrb- some of he contemporary have a lively remembrance of the eagerness with which while still a student he travel into field at that period beyond the somewhat narrow range of academic study professor maurice at one time dr pusey at another be he delighted companion in explore the dialogue of plato mr gladstone ` remember he speaking of milton 's prose work with great fervor when they be at eton together ' and add the confession -- interesting alike as regard both the young student -- ' i think it be from he mouth i first learn that milton have write any prose ' this affection for those soul-stirring treatise of the great advocate of free speech and inquiry he always retain : they form he constant companion wherever he travel and there be many occasion in which they influence may be trace on he thought and language ' i would rather swallow a bushel of chaff than lose the precious grain of truth which may somewhere or other be scatter in it ' be a sentiment which though express in much later life be characteristic of he whole career in this spirit he listen with deep interest to the roll of theological controversy then rage at oxford though he be never carry away by its violence in after life he have little leisure to pursue the philosophic study commence at oxford but they take deep and permanent hold on he mind and form in fact the groundwork of he great practical ability this be well state by sir frederick bruce : -- in elgin -lrb- to use the distinction of coleridge whose philosophy he have thoroughly master -rrb- the reason and understanding be both largely developed and both admirably balanced and in this combination lay the secret of he success in so many sphere of action so different in they characteristic so alike in they difficulty the process he go through be always the same he set himself to work to form in he own mind a clear idea of each of the constituent part of the problem with which he have to deal this he effect partly by read but still more by conversation with special man and by that extraordinary logical power of mind and penetration which not only enable he to get out of every man all he have in he but which reveal to those man themselves a knowledge of they own imperfect and crude conception and make they constantly unwilling witness or reluctant adherent to view which originally they be prepare to oppose to test the accuracy of they statement and observation and to discriminate between what be fact and what be prejudice or misconception he make use of the higher faculty of cultivate reason which enable he by he deep insight into the universal principle of human nature of form of government & c to bring to the consideration of particular fact the light of a a priori knowledge of what be to be expect under particular circumstance the result be that in a incredibly short time and with little apparent study or effort he attain a accurate and clear conception of the essential fact before he and be thus enable to strike out a course which he could consistently pursue amidst all difficulty because it be in harmony with the actual fact and the permanent condition of the problem he have to solve -lrb- sidenote : training for public life -rrb- the year which follow the completion of he academical study -- those golden year which generally determine the complexion of a man 's future life -- be not devote in he case to any definite pursuit for though he enter himself of lincoln 's inn in June 1835 he do not appear to have ever embark in the professional study of law the scanty notice which remain of this period show he chiefly reside at broomhall where in he father 's absence he take he place in the affair of the county of fife command he troop of yeomanry now preside at a farmer ' dinner for which be have write a appropriate song now at the request of dr chalmer speak at a public meeting in favor of church extension at one time we hear of long solitary ride over field and fall during which the thought and feeling that stir in he would take the shape of a sonnet or a poem to be confide to one of he sister at another time he be keep up a regular correspondence on abstruse question of philosophy with he brother frederick still at oxford in these pursuit as well as in the somewhat harass occupation of disentangle the family property from its embarrassment be be prepare himself for future usefulness by the exercise of the same industry and patience the same grasp both of detail and of general purpose which be show in the political career gradually dawn upon he it be observe that whatsoever he hand find to do he do it with all he might as well as with a judgment and discretion beyond he year and a tact akin to genius he be undergo perhaps the best training for the varied duty to which he be to be call -- that peculiarly british ` discipline of mind body and heart ' to which observer like bunsen attribute the effectiveness of england 's public man as early as 1834 when he have barely complete he twenty-third year he publish a letter to the elector of great britain with the view of vindicate the policy and the position of the tory leader more especially of the duke of wellington a similar motive the desire of protest against a monopoly of liberal sentiment by the whig and show in he own person that a tory be not necessarily a narrow bigot impel he to offer himself as a candidate at the election of 1837 on the occurrence of a unexpected vacancy in the representation of fifeshire but come forward at a moment 's warning he never have any chance of success and be defeat by a large majority -lrb- sidenote : mp for southampton -rrb- in the year 1840 george lord bruce the eldest son of lord elgin by he first wife die unmarried and jame become heir to the earldom on April 22 1841 he marry elizabeth mary daughter of mr cl cum bruce at the general election in July of the same year he stand for the borough of southampton and be return at the head of the poll he political view at this time be very much those which have since be call ` liberal conservative ' speaking at a great banquet at southampton he say -- i be a conservative not upon principle of exclusionism -- not from narrowness of view or illiberality of sentiment -- but because i believe that we admirable constitution on principle more exalted and under sanction more holy than those which owenism or socialism can boast proclaim between man of all class and degree in the body politic a sacred bond of brotherhood in the recognition of a common warfare here and a common hope hereafter i be a conservative not because i be adverse to improvement not because i be unwilling to repair what be waste or to supply what be defective in the political fabric but because i be satisfied that in order to improve effectually you must be resolve most religiously to preserve i be a conservative because i believe that the institution of we country religious as well as civil be wisely adapt when duly and faithfully administer to promote not the interest of any class or class exclusively but the happiness and welfare of the great body of the people and because i feel that on the maintenance of these institution not only the economical prosperity of england but what be yet more important the virtue that distinguish and adorn the english character under god mainly depend -lrb- sidenote : speech on the address -rrb- parliament meet on August 19 and on the 24th the new member second the amendment on the address in a speech of great promise in the course of it he profess himself a friend to free trade but free trade as explain and vindicate by mr huskisson : -- he should at all time be prepare to vote for a free trade on principle of reciprocity due regard be have to the interest which have grow up under we present commercial system without which as he conceive the rights of the labor class could not be protect much have be on various occasion say about the interest of the capitalist and the landlord but unless the measure of a government be direct equally to secure the rights of the work class they never should be support by a vote of he it be true that the landlord might derive some increase value to he property from the increase of factory and other building upon it and that the capitalist might more advantageously invest he capital or he might withdraw it from a sinking concern but the only capital of the labourer be he skill in he own particular walk and it be a mockery to tell he that he could find a satisfactory compensation elsewhere but the most characteristic part of he speech be that in which he comment on the ` harsh severe and unjust term ' in which it have be the fashion to designate those who have take a opposite view on these question to that take by she majesty 's government : -- in a day -lrb- he say -rrb- when all monopoly be denounce i must he permit to say that to my mind the monopoly which be the most intolerable and odious be the pretension to the monopoly of public virtue the amendment be carry by a large majority lord melbourne resign and sir robert peel become prime minister about the same time by the death of he father and he own succession to the peerage the young lord 's brief career in the house of common be close for ever no scottish peer be eligible accord to the commonly receive opinion to sit in the lower house he appear indeed to have have at one time a idea of press the question but he abandon this intention on finding that it have be entertain twenty-five year before by lord aberdeen and give up by he on the ground that the majority of the scottish peer look upon the proposal as lower to they body and as imply inferiority on they part to the english peer -lrb- sidenote : governor of jamaica -rrb- at this time it seem as if the fair promise of eloquence and statesmanship have be show to public life only to be withdraw from it but a path be about to be open lead to a new field of action distant indeed and often thankless but give scope for the exercise of gift both of mind and character which can rarely be exhibit in a parliamentary career in march 1842 at the early age of thirty he be select by lord stanley who be then secretary for the colony for the important post of governor of jamaica -lrb- 1 -rrb- the family seat in fifeshire -lrb- 2 -rrb- the most distinguish of all those competitor have bear he testimony to the truth of this expression ' i well remember ' mr gladstone write after he death place he as to the natural gift of eloquence at the head of all those i know either at eton or at the university ' -lrb- 3 -rrb- he elder brother -lrb- 4 -rrb- ` we be dispose in fact to regard the question of university extension in this sense as depend entirely on the possibility of reduce the time require for a university degree and we should like to see more attention pay to this point the opinion be strongly and widely entertain that student now stay too long at the public school and university and that vote man ought not to be engage in the mere preparatory study of they life up to the age of twenty-three or twenty-four ' -- _ time _ may 22 1869 -lrb- 5 -rrb- there remain a memorandum in he handwriting of a systematic course of study to be pursue for he degree in which two point be remarkable -- 1st the broad and liberal spirit in which it be conceive 2ndly that the whole be base on the bible ancient history together with aristotle 's politics and the ancient orator be to be read ` in connection with the bible history ' with the view of see ` how all hang upon each other and develop the lead scheme of providence ' the various branch of mental and moral science he propose in like manner ` to hinge upon the new testament as constitute in another line the history of moral and intellectual development ' chapter ii jamaica shipwreck -- death of lady elgin -- position of a british connexion -- resignation -- appointment to canada -lrb- sidenote : shipwreck -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : death of lady elgin -rrb- lord elgin sail for jamaica in the middle of April 1842 the west indian steamer at that time hold they rendezvous for the collection and distribution of the mail not as now at st thoma but at a little island call turk 's island a mere sandbank hedge with coral reef the vessel in which lord elgin be a passenger make this island during the night but the captain over anxious to keep he time hold on towards the shore they strike on a spike of coral which pierce the ship 's side and hold she impale fortunately so for she be thus prevent from back out to sea and founder with all hand as other vessel do though the ship itself become a total wreck no life be lose and nearly everything of value be save but from the shock of that night lady elgin though apparently little alarmed at the time never recover two month afterwards in give birth to a daughter now lady elma thurlow she be seize with violent convulsion which be nearly fatal and though to the surprise of the medical man she rally from this attack she health be seriously impaired and she die in the summer of the following year -lrb- sidenote : position of a governor in a west indian colony -rrb- there be probably few situation of greater difficulty and delicacy than that of the governor of a british colony which possess representative institution a constitutional sovereign but with frail and temporary tenure he be expect not to reign only but to govern and to govern under the order of a distant minister who if he have one eye on the colony must keep the other on home politics thus without any power in himself he be a meeting-point of two different and generally antagonistic force -- the will of the imperial government and the will of the local legislature to act in harmony with both these force and to bring they into something of harmony with each other require under the most favourable circumstance a rare union of firmness with patience and tact but the difficulty be much aggravate in a west indian colony in the early day of emancipation -lrb- sidenote : such as jamaica -rrb- here the local legislature be a democratic oligarchy partly compose of landowner but chiefly of overseer with no permanent stake in the country and this legislature have to be induce to pass measure for the benefit of those very black of whose enforced service they have be deprive and whose pay labor they find it difficult to obtain add to this that in jamaica a long period of contention with the mother-country have leave a feeling of bitter resentment for the past and sullen despondency as regard the future moreover the balance have to be hold between the church of england on the one hand which be in possession of all the ecclesiastical endowment and probably of all the learning and cultivation of the island and on the other hand the various sect especially that of the baptist who have fight vigorously for the negro in the battle of emancipation now hold undisputed sway over they mind and who as be natural find it difficult to abandon the position of demagogue and agitator lord elgin be at once fortunate and unfortunate in come after the most conciliatory and popular of governor sir c metcalfe the island be in a state of peace and harmony which have be long unknown to it but the singular affection which metcalfe have inspire in all class make they look forward with the most gloomy foreboding to the advent of he successor -lrb- sidenote : state of opinion in the island be often say in apology for such person that they be after all sincere that they be deceive rather than deceiver that they do not ask other to adopt opinion which they have not heartily accept you who be enter upon the useful and honorable career of the british merchant for you be now stand on the lower step of a ladder which when it be mount with diligence and circumspection lead always to respectability not unfrequently to high honor and distinction bear in mind then that the quality which ought chiefly to distinguish those who aspire to exercise a control and direct influence in any department of human action from those who have only a subordinate part to play be the knowledge of principle and general law a few example will make the truth of this proposition apparent to you take for instance the case of the builder the mason and carpenter must know how to hew the stone and square the timber and follow out faithfully the work plan place in they hand but the architect must know much more than this he must be acquaint with the principle of proportion and form he must know the law which regulate the distribution of heat light and air in order that he may give to each part of a complicated structure its due share of these advantage and combine the multifarious detail into a consistent whole take again the case of the seaman it be enough for the steersman that he watch certain symptom in the sky and on the wave that he note the shift of the wind and compass and attend to certain precise rule which have be give he for he guidance but the master of the ship if he be be monarchical in its sentiment can not of course be measure merely by its recognize power -lrb- sidenote : influence of a governor under responsible government -rrb- those who be most ready to concur : demand for labor -rrb- from the nature of the business the lumber trade fall necessarily in a great measure into the hand of person of capital who employ large body of man at point far remove from the result of the experiment have be entirely satisfactory the bearing of the lumbering business on the settlement of the country be a point well worthy of notice the farmer who undertake to cultivate unreclaimed land in new country generally find that not only do every step of advance which he make in the wilderness by remove he from the centre of trade and civilisation enhance the cost of all he have to purchase but that moreover it diminish the value of what he have to sell it be not so however with the farmer who follow in the wake of the lumberman he find on the contrary in the want of the latter a ready demand for all that he produce at a price not only equal to that procurable in the ordinary mart but increase by the cost of transport from they to the scene of the lumbering operation this circumstance no doubt powerfully contribute to promote the settlement of those district and attract population to section of the country which in the absence of any such inducement would probably remain for long period uninhabited -lrb- 4 -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : wild land -rrb- the large amount of wild land hold by individual and corporation render the disposal of the public domain a question of less urgency in this than in some other colony opinion in the province run strongly in favor of facilitate its acquisition in small lot by actual settler and of put all possible obstacle in the way of its fall into the hand of speculator this opinion be found no doubt in part on a jealousy of great landholder but it be mainly i apprehend attributable to a sense of the inconvenience and damage which be experience in young country when considerable tract of land be keep out of the market in the midst of district that be in course of settlement to this feeling much of the hostility to the ` clergy reserve ' be originally due the upset price of government wild land in canada vary from 7_s _ 6_d _ currency to 1_s _ currency a acre accord to quality and by the rule of the crown land department now in force it be concede at these rate except in special case in lot of not more than 200 acre on condition of actual settlement of erect a dwelling-house and clearing one-fourth of the lot before the patent can be obtain the price be payable in some part of the country in ten yearly instalment in other in five with interest in both case from the date of sale i have little faith in the efficacy of such device to compel actual settlement they hinder the free circulation of capital be easily evade and seem to be especially out of place where wild land be subject to taxation for municipal purpose as be the case in upper canada -lrb- 5 -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : seigniorial tenure -rrb- a good deal of land in lower canada be hold in seigniory under a species of feudal tenure with respect to the condition of which a controversy have arise which threaten unless some equitable mode of adjust it be speedily devise to be productive of very serious consequence a certain class of jurist contend that by the custom of the country establish before its conquest by great britain the seignior be bind to concede they land in lot of about 100 acre to the first applicant in consideration of the payment of certain due and of a rent which never as they allege exceed one penny a acre and they quote edict of the french monarch to show that the governor and intendant when the seignior be contumacious could seize the land and make the concession in spite of he take the rent for the crown the seignior on the other hand plead the decision of the court since the conquest in vindication of they claim to receive such rent as they can bargain for independently of this controversy the incident of the tenure be in other respects calculate to exercise a unfavourable influence on the progress of the province and its abolition if it could be effect without injustice would no doubt be a highly beneficial measure -lrb- 6 -rrb- still more important and interesting at this time accordingly it rest with the freeholder and householder of each school section to decide whether they will support they school by voluntary subscription by rate bill for each pupil attend the school the question of religious instruction as connect with the common school system present even more than ordinary difficulty in a community where there be so much diversity of opinion on religious subject and where all denomination be in the eye of the law on a footing of entire equality it be lay down as a fundamental principle that as the common school be not board but day school and as the pupil be under the care of they parent or guardian during the Sunday and a considerable portion of each week day it be not intend that the function of the common school teacher should supersede those of the parent and pastor of the child accordingly the law contents itself with provide on this head ` that in any model or common school establish under this act no child shall be require to read or be allow to receive such religious instruction as they parent or guardian shall desire accord to the general regulation which shall be provide accord to law ' and it authorise under certain regulation denomination be make _ ex officio _ visitor of the school in township city town or village where they reside or have pastoral charge the chief superintendent dr ryerson remark on this head : -lrb- nor prohibit recognize the duty of pastor and parent as well as of school trustee and teacher and consider the unite labor of all as constitute the system of education for the youth of the country ' any hope of be able to do anything for they benefit -lrb- sidenote : aboriginal tribe -rrb- it be painful to turn from review the progress of the european population and they descendant establish in ` narrative of the earl of elgin 's mission to china and japan ' by laurence oliphant then private secretary to lord elgin to that work we must refer we reader for a full and complete as well as authentic account of the occurrence which give occasion to the follow letter a brief sketch only will here be give -lrb- sidenote : origin of the mission -rrb- on October 8 1856 a _ lorcha _ name ` arrow ' register as a british vessel and carry a british flag be board by the authority of canton the flag tear down and the crew carry away as prisoner such be the english account the chinese deny that any flag be fly at the time of the capture : the british ownership of the vessel they maintain be never more than colourable and have expire a month before : the crew be all they own subject apprehend on a charge of piracy the english authority refuse to listen to this they insist on a write apology for the insult to they flag and the formal restitution of the capture sailor and when these demand be refuse or incompletely fulfil they summon the fleet in the hope that a moderate amount of pressure would lead to the require concession shortly after find arm in they hand they think it a good opportunity to enforce the fulfilment of certain ` long-evaded treaty obligation ' include the right for all foreign representative of free access to the authority and the city of canton with this view fort after fort suburb after suburb be take or demolish but the chinese after they manner would neither yield nor fight and contented themselves with offer large reward for the head of every englishman when this state of matter be report to england it be bring before the house of common on a motion by mr cobden condemnatory of ` the violent measure resort to at canton in the late affair of the arrow ' the motion support by mr gladstone in one of he splendid burst of rhetoric be carry against the government by a majority of sixteen in a full and excited house on the morning of February 26 1857 but lord palmerston refuse to accept the adverse vote as express the will of the people he appeal to the constituency candidly tell the house that pend that appeal ` there would be no change and could be no change in the policy of the government with respect to event in china ' at the same time he intimate that a special envoy would be send out to supersede the local authority arm with full power to settle the relation between england and china on a broad and solid basis -lrb- sidenote : appointment of lord elgin -rrb- but where be the man who at a juncture so critical in face of a adverse vote of the house of common on the chance of its be rescind by the country could be trust with so delicate a mission who could be rely on in the conduct of such a expedition against a foe alike stubborn and weak to go far enough and yet not too far -- to carry he point by diplomatic skill and force of character with the least possible infringement of the law of humanity a man with the ability and resolution to insure success and the native strength that can afford to be merciful after ` anxious deliberation ' the choice of the government fall upon lord elgin how on the voyage to china he be meet half-way by the news of the indian mutiny how promptly and magnanimously he take on himself the responsibility of sacrifice the success of he own expedition by divert the troops from china to india how after many weary month of enforced inactivity the expedition be resume and carry through numberless thwarting to a successful issue -- these be matter of history with which every reader must be acquaint but those who be most familiar with the event may find a interest in the following extract from private letter write at the time by the chief actor in the drama they be take hm ` caradoc ' -- may 2nd _ -- i have just return to my ship after spend a few hour on shore and visit lord lyon in he magnificent prince albert how beautiful malta be with its narrow street gorgeous church and impregnable fortification i land at about six and walk up to the palace and write my name in the governor 's book who reside out of town i then take a turn through the town and go to the of alexandrium the beast too camel oxen donkey show sign of the fertility of the soil in they sleekness what might not be make of this country if it be wisely guide -lrb- sidenote : cross the desert -rrb- _ steamer ` bentinck ' -- Sunday may 10th _ -- i write to you from the neighborhood of mount sinaus which we pass at a early hour this morning glide through a sea of most transparent glass with view this grave intelligence as a inducement to press on to china i write officially to clarendon to say that if this intelligence be confirm it might have a tendency to lower we prestige in the east and to increase the influence of the party oppose to reason in china that this state of affair might make it more than ever necessary that i should endeavor to bring matter in china to a issue at the earliest moment so as to anticipate this mischief and to place the regiment destine for china at the disposal of government for service elsewhere _ may 29th _ -- we be now near the close of we voyage the chinese in a manner which it be very difficult to justify and yet they treachery and cruelty come out so strongly at time as to make almost anything appear justifiable -lrb- sidenote : penang -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : bishop of labuan -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : character of chinese -rrb- _ penang -- June 1st _ -- we have just return to we vessel after a few hour spend on shore or rather i have oriental : that when a new boy come they generally get up a fight and let he earn he place by he prowess but there be no manage they without pretty severe punishment indeed he say that if a boy be in fault the other do not at all like he not be well punish they seem to think that it be a injustice to the rest if this be omit i be about to do with a strange people so much to admire in they and yet with a perversity of disposition which make it absolutely necessary if you be to live with they at all to treat they severely sometimes almost cruelly they have such a overweening esteem for themselves that they become unbearable unless they be constantly remind that other be as good as they the bishop seem to think that it would be a very good thing if the rajah be to go home for a time -lrb- sidenote : ignorance of the chinese language -rrb- _ June 11th _ -- at half-past four this morning the ` shannon ' arrive captain peel come up to breakfast he have make a quick passage as he to take I when he leave england on Tuesday at noon the chinese arrive with a address to I i have a reply prepared which be translate into malay and read by a native it be a most extraordinary shut up they shop which be they constitutional mode of express dissatisfaction it be immediately infer in certain quarter that the chinese intend out of sympathy with the cantonese to murder all the european luckily the governor think it advisable to explain to they what the obnoxious ordinance really mean before proceed to exterminate they and a few hour of explanation have the effect of induce they to re-open they shop and go on quietly with they usual avocation just the same thing happen at penang there too because the chinaman show some disinclination to obey regulation of police which -rrb- _ hm ` furious ' canton river -- January 2nd 1858 _ -- the last week have be a very eventful one : not one of unmixed satisfaction to I because of course there be a great deal that be painful January 24th _ -- baron gro and i be converse together yesterday on affair in this quarter and among other thing he tell I that we be both much reproach for we laxity and that i be more blame on that account than he i say to he : ' i can praise you on many account my dear baron but i can not compliment you on be a greater brute than i be ' whatever be the feeling of the british resident and whatever excuse may be make for it the consistent humanity show both in the take and in the occupation of the city do not fail to strike mr reed the plenipotentiary of the united state who write to lord elgin : ' i can not omit this opportunity of most sincerely congratulating you on the success at canton the great success of a bloodless victory the merit of which i be sure be mainly due to you lordship 's gentle and discreet counsel my countryman will i be sure appreciate it ' ` this ' observe lord elgin from the representative of the united state be gratify both personally and politically ' _ January 28th _ -- i be glad to say that this mail convey on the whole a satisfactory report of the progress of affair though this letter put you in possession of all the ebb and flow which have take place during the fortnight i send a leaf of geranium which i culled in the garden of the tartar general -lrb- sidenote : canton prison -rrb- _ January 31st _ -- i visit yesterday two of the canton prison and witness there some sight of horror beyond what i could have picture to myself many of the inmate be so reduce by disease and starvation that they limb be not as thick as my wrist one man who be in this condition be in the receptacle for untried prisoner and say he have be there seven year in one of the court which we enter there be a cell close in by a double row of upright post which be the common style of gate at canton and i be attract to it by the groan of its inmate i desire it to be open and such a spectacle as it present the prisoner be cover with sore produce by severe beating one be already dead and the rat -- but i can not go further in description the other could hardly crawl they be so emaciated and my conviction be that they be shut in there to die the prison authority state that they have escape at the time of the bombardment for which they have be punish as we see if the statement be true they must have be systematically starve since they recapture we pretext for visit the prison be to discover whether any european or person who have be in the service of or have have relation with european be confine in they we take out some who profess to belong to the latter class i go a step further by take out a poor boy of fifteen whom we find in chain but so weak that when we take they off he be unable to stand i tell mr parke to take he to pehkwei from I as a sample of the manner in which he prison be manage _ February 2nd _ -- pehkweus be very indignant at we visit to he prison and hint that he would make away with himself in a letter which he write to I on the subject however he be oblige to admit that some of the thing we find be very bad and quite against the chinese law on review the whole i must admit that except in the case of the one cell that i have describe it be rather neglect want of food medical care cleanliness & c than positive cruelty of which one find evidence in the prison \* \* \* \* \* -lrb- sidenote : move northwards -rrb- canton the impregnable have be take and be in the military occupation of the ally force yeh the terror of barbarian be a captive beyond the sea so completely be all resistance sidenote : swatow -rrb- _ hm ` furious ' swatow -- march 5th _ -- i be again on the wide ocean though for the moment at anchor the settlement here be against treaty it consist mainly of agent of the much they own way they be master of the situation pay no duty except tonnage due which be pay by they at about one-third of the amount pay by native vessel of the same burthen -lrb- sidenote : mr burn -rrb- hear that mr burn a missionary whose case be narrate in the series of ` insult by the chinese authority ' submit to parliament -lrb- he have be in fact very kindly treat as he himself the blow would be lay on by a friendly hand and that if he keep he cheek loose he would not feel they much -lrb- sidenote : amoy -rrb- _ march 8th _ -- we be enter foochow a most beautiful day the sea discover eight symbol on the back of a tortoise these multiply into themselves make sixty-four which constitute the book of fate it appear that my lot be the first of the eight and therefore the best that can be get -lrb- sidenote : ningpo -rrb- _ ningpo -- march 18th _ -- we arrive here yesterday and i have be walk both day about the town with mr meadow the author who be vice-consul here i be which the native show the most friendly disposition towards foreigner to the resident trader the inference be obvious : the severity be the cause of the friendly disposition and it have only to be apply elsewhere to produce the like result with evident satisfaction lord elgin set himself in a official despatch to refute this reasoning after observe that the native show rather a exaggeration than a defect of the desire to live peaceably with foreigner he proceed : -- the state of ningpo in this respect furnish they favorite and perhaps most plausible argument to that class of person who advocate what be style a vigorous policy in china in other word a policy which consist in resort to the most violent measure of coercion and repression on the slenderest provocation they say ` remember what happen at ningpo during the last war and observe the consideration and respect which be evince towards you there treat other town in china likewise and the result will be the same ' i question the soundness of this inference ningpo be situate on the south-eastern verge of the mighty valley of the yang-tze-kiang which be inhabit by a population the most inoffensive perhaps both by disposition and habit of any on the surface of the earth they amenity towards the foreigner be due i apprehend to temperament as much at least as to the recollection of the violence which they may have sustain at he hand i have make it a point whenever i have meet missionary or other who have penetrate into the interior from ningpo and shangha to ask they what treatment they experience on those expedition and the answer have almost invariably be that at point remote from those to which foreigner have access there be no diminution but on the contrary rather a enhancement of the courtesy exhibit towards they by the native -lrb- sidenote : missionary school -rrb- _ hm ` furious ' -- march 20th _ -- yesterday i call on a clergyman to see miss aldersey -- a remarkable lady who come out we christian dignify with the name of war in these country idol be rip up in the hope of find treasure in they temple ornament seize and in short no sort of consideration be show for the religious feeling of the native the following notice of the same sacred island occur in one of he despatch : -- i trust that i may be permit to offer one remark in reference to potou a islet adjoining chusan which i touch at on my way from the latter place to chapoo little information of course be to be gather there on question directly affect trade or politics for it be a holy spot exclusively appropriate to temple in tinsel and bonz in rag but it be impossible to wander over it as i do visit with entire impunity its most sacred recess without be forcibly remind of the fact that one at least of the obstacle to intercourse between nation which operate most powerfully in many part especially of the east can hardly be say to exist in china the buddhistic faith do not seem to excite in the popular mind any bigoted antipathy to the professor of other creed the owner of the humblest dwelling almost invariably offer to the foreigner who enter it the hospitable tea-cup without any apparent apprehension that he guest by use will defile it and priest and worshipper attach no idea of profanation to the presence of the stranger in the joss-house this be a fact as i humbly conceive not without its significance when we come to consider what prospect there may be of we be able to extend and multiply relation of commerce and amity with this industrious portion of the human race the private journal proceeds : -- _ march 24th _ -- we be glide through a perfectly smooth sea with island on both side of we on a beautifully calm and clear day warmer than of late but still tart enough to feel healthy we pass a fleet of some hundred of junk proceed northward under convoy of some lorcha of the ` arrow ' class carry flag which they probably have no right to these lorcha exact a sort of black mail from the junk and plunder they whenever it be more profitable to do so than to protect they they often have european on board poor yeh have suffer severely for we sin in respect to this description of craft we be on we way to chapoo now a port not open to trade but one which i be order by the government to induce the chinese to open as it be very little out of the way to shanghae i wish to look at it in pass -lrb- sidenote : chapoo -rrb- _ march 25th _ -- we reach chapoo at about 5 pm i do not land but some of the party do and mount a hill from whence they look down upon a walled town of no great size and a plain perfectly flat stretch for any number of mile beyond it the people as usual be civil and make no difficulty although we have no right to land there the bay in righteousness and hate iniquity and all this keep I in a perpetual boil -lrb- sidenote : treaty sign -rrb- _ June 29th _ -- i have not write for some day but they have be busy one we go on fighting they head if they give way on these point the resident minister at pekin i consider far the most important matter gain by the treaty the power to trade in the interior hardly less so i have at stake they would not raise difficulty on every other i send for the admiral give he a hint that there be a great opportunity for england that all the power be desert I on a point which they have _ all _ in not insist on it would he back I this be the forenoon of Saturday 26th the treaty be to be sign in the evening i may mention as a proof of the state of people 's mind that admiral seymor tell I that the french admiral have urge he to dine with he assure he that no treaty would be sign that day well i send frederick to the imperial commissioner to tell they that i be indignant beyond all expression at they have attempt to communicate with I through third party that i be ready to sign at once the treaty as it stand but that if they delay or retract i should consider negotiation at a end go to pekin and demand a great deal more & c frederick execute this most difficult task admirably and at 6 pm i sign the treaty of tientsin i be now anxiously wait some communication from pekin till the emperor accept the treaty i shall hardly feel safe please god he may ratify without delay i be sure that i express the wish just as much in the interest of china as in ours though i have be force to act almost brutally i be china 's friend in all this -lrb- sidenote : article of the treaty -rrb- it may be well here to recapitulate the chief article of the treaty thus conclude which may be briefly sum up as follow : -- the queen of great britain to be at liberty if she see fit to appoint a ambassador who may reside permanently at pekin or may visit it occasionally at the option of the british government protestant and roman catholic to be alike entitle to the protection of the chinese authority british subject to be at liberty to travel to all part of the interior under passport issue by they consul british ship to be at liberty to trade upon the great river -lrb- yangtze -rrb- five additional port to be open to trade the tariff fix by the treaty of nankin to be revise british subject to have the option of clear they goods of all transit duty by payment of a single charge to be calculate as nearly as possible at the rate of 2-1\/2 per cent _ ad valorem _ the character ` i ' -lrb- barbarian -rrb- to be no longer apply in official document to british subject the chinese to pay 2000000 tael -lrb- about 650000_l _ -rrb- for loss at canton and a equal sum for the expense of the war -lrb- sidenote : reason for moderation -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : right of send a ambassador -rrb- in bring this treaty to a conclusion lord elgin might have say of himself as truly as of the brother who have so ably help he in arrange its term that he ` feel very sensibly the painfulness of the position of a negotiator who have to treat with person who yield nothing to reason and everything to fear and who be at the same time profoundly ignorant both of the subject under discussion and of they own real interest ' moreover he have constantly to recollect that under the ` most favored nation ' clause every concession make to british subject would be claim by the subject or person call themselves the subject of other power by whom they be only too likely to be employ for the promotion of rebellion and disorder within the empire or for the establishment of privileged smuggling and piracy along its coast and up its river in all these circumstance he see grounds for exercise forbearance and moderation and he forbearance and moderation be reward by the readiness with which the emperor sanction the treaty and the amicable manner in which its detail be subsequently settle one exception there be to this moderation on he part and to this readiness on theirs viz he insist against the earnest remonstrance of the imperial commissioner back by the intercession of the russian and american envoy on the right of send a ambassador to pekin but it be a exception of that kind which be say to prove the rule for the stipulation be one which could not lead to abuse and which would be conducive as he believe in the highest decree to the true interest of both the contracting party he be convince that so long as the system of entrust the conduct of foreign affair to a provincial government endure there could be no security for the maintenance of pacific relation on the one hand the provincial governor be entirely without any sentiment of nationality caring for nothing but the interest of they own province : nor be they in a position to exercise any independence of judgment they life and fortune be absolutely at the disposal of a jealous government so that it be generally they most prudent course to allow any abuse to pass unnoticed rather than risk they head by report unwelcome truth on the other land the central government in which alone a national feeling and a independent judgment be to be look for be profoundly ignorant on all question of foreign policy and must continue to be so as long as the department for foreign affair be establish in the province for these reason he regard the principle that a british minister might henceforth reside at pekin and hold direct intercourse with imperial minister at the capital as be of all the concession in the treaty the one pregnant with the most important consequence -lrb- 2 -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : to be keep in reserve -rrb- but the right once secure he be very desirous that it should be exercise with all possible consideration for the long-cherished prejudice of the chinese on the subject who look forward with the utmost horror to the invasion of they capital by foreign minister with they wife and establishment these latter be as it appear in they eye more formidable than the minister themselves accordingly when the imperial commissioner address to he a very temperate and respectful communication urge that the exercise of the treaty-right in question would be of serious prejudice to china mainly because in the present crisis of she domestic trouble it would tend to cause a loss of respect for they government in the mind of she subject he gladly forward they memorial to the government in england support it with the strong expression of he own opinion that ` if she majesty 's ambassador should be properly receive at pekin when the ratification be exchange next year it would be expedient that she majesty 's representative in china should be instruct to choose a place of residence elsewhere than at pekin and to make he visit either periodical or only as frequent as the exigency of the public service might require ' with much shrewdness he point out that the actual presence of a minister hi a place so uncongenial especially during the winter month when the thermometer fall to 40 ° below zero might possibly be to the mandarin mind less awe-inspiring than the knowledge of the fact that he have the power to take up he abode there whenever the conduct of the chinese government give occasion and that thus the policy which he recommend would ` leave in the hand of she majesty 's government to be wield at its will a moral lever of the most powerful description to secure the faithful observance of the treaty in all time to come ' -lrb- sidenote : return of road and canal toll-free and should moreover be relieved altogether from charge to which they would be liable if the property of native on the other hand experience have teach we the inconvenience -rrb- on the whole i consider it the most interesting expedition i ever make the total absence of anything like want among the people they joyous though polite and respectful demeanor the combination warfare -rrb- _ November 24th -- ten be _ -- we set off this morning at about 6 be in pass the fleet we beg from the commander the loan of a pilot he prove to be a cantonese so that the active spirit on both side seem to come from that quarter we ask he why the imperialist do not take woohoo he say they have no gun of a sufficient size to do anything against the fort but that about twice a month they have a fight on shore they cut off the head of rebel and _ vice versâ _ when they catch each other which do not seem to happen very often the war in short seem to be carry on in a very soft manner but it must do a great deal of mischief to the country while i be dress i be call out of my cabin to see a fight go on on the right bank of the river the rebel occupy some hill where they be wave flag gallantly and the imperialist be below they in a plain we see only two or three cannon shot fire while we pass as thing be carry on one do not see why this war should not last for ever my ` you great nation : ' that it should not happen again & c wade tell they that the same thing have occur at nankin and that we have destroy the peccant fort they answer that they be aware of what have difficulty of get at fact -rrb- the knowledge of the chinese language possess by messr wade and lay enable I to enter without difficulty into communication with the inhabitant of the town and rural district which we visit at various point in we progress we wander unarmed and unattended in party of three or four to a distance of several mile from the bank of the river and we never experience at the hand of the native anything but courtesy mingle with a certain amount of not very obtrusive curiosity notwithstanding however these favourable opportunity the budget of statistical fact which i be able to collect be hardly as considerable as i could have desire chinaman of the humbler class be not much addict to reflection and when subject to cross-examination by person greedy of information they be apt to consider the proceed a strange one and to suspect that it must be prompt by some exceedingly bad motive moreover have be civilised for many generation they carry politeness so far that in answer a question it be always they chief endeavor to say what they suppose they questioner will be best please to hear if therefore the knowledge of a fact be to be arrive at it be above all thing necessary that the inquiry bear a tint so neutral that the person to whom it be address shall find it impossible to reflect its color in he reply he will then sometimes in he confusion blunder into a truthful answer but he do so generally with a bashful air indicative of the painful consciousness that he have be reluctantly violate the rule of good breed a search after accurate statistics under such condition be not unattended with difficulty -lrb- sidenote : exaggerated report of population -rrb- i be confirm by what i have witness on this expedition in the doubt which i have long entertain hankow at 8000000 i doubt much whether it now amount in the aggregate to 1000000 and even when they be flourish i can not conceive where 3000000 of human being could have be stow away in they -lrb- i arrive at the conclusion that for the most part they hold they land which be of very limited extent in full property from the crown subject to certain annual charge of no very exorbitant amount and that these advantage improve by assiduous industry supply abundantly they simple want whether in respect of food or clothing in the street of city in china some deplorable object be to be meet with as must always be the case where mendicity be a legalised institution but i be incline to think that the rigor with which the duty of relationship be enforce operate as a powerful check on pauperism a girl 's husband when she marry would be bind to support the adopt mother by the judicious investment of a dollar in this timely purchase the worthy woman thus secure for herself a provision for old age and a security which she probably appreciate yet more highly for decent burial when she die -lrb- sidenote : manufacture -rrb- my general impression be that british manufacturer will have to exert the tartar seem to be in greater force than be suppose the officer in command -lrb- rightly or wrongly i know not which -rrb- resolve to consider the expedition merely a reconnaissance and to retire on which they be find be firm and fit for cavalry and be about four mile from the peiho fort this be a very nasty place the country around be all under water and it be impossible to get through it
