do not like to be too confident -lrb- sidenote : the peiho -rrb- _ August 25th -- noon _ -- high and dry at about fifteen mile below tientsin this must remind you of some of my letter from the yangtze two year ago we start this morning at 630 in the ` granada : ' the general and i with both we staff we have go on famously to this point scrape through the mud occasionally with success in round a corner however at which a french gunboat have already stick before we we have run upon a bank it be very strange to I to be go up the peiho river again the fertility of the plain through which it run strike I more than it do formerly the harvest be at hand and the crop clothe it luxuriantly the poor people in the village do not appear to fear we much we treat they well before and they expect similar treatment again the admiral do he work of occupy tientsin well he have great quality -lrb- sidenote : tientsin -rrb- _ tientsin -- Sunday August 26th _ -- we reach this place about midnight it be about the most nervous operation at which i ever assist go round the sharp turn with this long ship by moonlight i have a moment of painful _ saisissement _ when i feel almost certain that we should run into my dear colleague gro who have ground in a little gunboat at one of the worst bend of the river we only save he by drop a anchor from the stern and go backwards full speed the yangtze be bad enough but we never use to go on at night and there be no danger of collision this ship look also as if she would go head over heel much more easily than the ` furious ' i be wait for parke and the general before i decide as to landing & c be it not strange to be here immediately ahead of we be the yamun where gro and i spend the eventful week in 1858 which precede the signature of the treaty of tientsin _ two pm _ -- we be to have the yamun in which reed and putiatine be lodge in 1858 a much better quarter than we old one and the general gro and i be all to lodge in it together -lrb- sidenote : chinese yamun -rrb- _ tientsin -- August 27th _ -- i have a very bad headache after i have send off the mail yesterday we ship have moreover get aground and be lie over so much on one side that it seem possible that she might topple over altogether under these circumstance and have the prospect of a very noisy night on board i determine to land and sleep in my yamun the portion of it dedicate to I consist of a regular chinese garden with rockwork and bridge and pond full of lotus leave and flowerpot of all dimension with shrub and flower in they surround on two side by wooden building contain room with carve woodwork and other chinese neatness it be the only house of a chinese gentleman i have ever inhabit for when i be here before i dwelt in a temple the mosquito be a little troublesome at first but i get my net up and sleep tolerably better than i should have do here for the iron ship get so heat by the sun during the day that they be never cool however fresh the night air may be -lrb- sidenote : negotiation -rrb- _ August 29th _ -- i intend to have tell you that i be send a stiff letter to my old friend kweiliang but in fact it have take some time and consultation with gro to settle its term and it be only now be translate yesterday afternoon the long-expected mail arrive shall i really eat my christmas dinner with you really many thing be more improbable than that i hope at one time that this letter might be despatch from pekin but as we have to meet commissioner here and to make a kind of supplementary treaty before proceed thither it be doubtful whether we shall accomplish this i be not sure that i like my present domicile as well as i do my domicile here in 1858 because although it be a great deal more _ orné _ it be proportionably hotter be surround by wall which we can not see over it be a great place with a infinite number of court and room of all size i should think several family must live in it unless the establishment of a chinese gentleman be very large indeed if kweiliang and co come into we term my present intention be to send at once to frederick officially and request he to come on to pekin he have be have some very troublesome work at shangha with the rebel indeed there be at present work enough for both of we in china _ September 1st _ -- kweiliang arrive last night and send I a hint that he intend to call on I to-day i send one in return to say that i would not see he until he have answer my letter i fear a little more bully will be necessary before we bring this stupid government up to the mark both yesterday and to-day i take a ride in the morning with grant i ride a horse of he a very nice one the sun become powerful very early but it be a charming climate now the abundance of all thing wonderful : beef and mutton at about threepence a pound peach grape and all sort of vegetable in plenty ice in profusion i daresay however that in six week ' time it may be very cold at one moment on the 2nd of September it really seem as if the object of the mission be achieve for the imperial commissioner -- one of whom be the same kweiliang who have conduct the negotiation in 1858 -- in a formal despatch give a positive assurance that the treaty of tientsin should be faithfully observe and that all the demand hitherto make should be concede in full a draft of convention be accordingly prepare on this basis but when it come to the point kweiliang and he colleague declare that they have no authority to sign it without refer to pekin and it become obvious that he either do not possess or do not at that moment wish it to be suppose that he possess power equal to those which he hold in 1858 although he previous language have be calculate to convey the opposite impression -lrb- sidenote : break off -rrb- here be clearly a deliberate design to create delay with the view of drag on negotiation into the winter it be indispensable lord elgin think to check this policy by a act of vigor and accordingly with the concurrence of baron gro he intimate to the imperial commissioner that in consequence of the want of good faith exhibit by they in assume the title of plenipotentiary when they could not exercise the authority which it imply and of the delay which the allege necessity of constant reference to pekin would occasion he have determine to proceed at once to tung-chow in the immediate neighborhood of the capital and to enter into no further negotiation with they until he should have reach that place _ September 8th _ -- i be at war again my idiotical chinaman have take to play trick which give I a excellent excuse for carry the army on to pekin it would be a long affair to tell you all the in and out but i be sure from what have come to pass during the last few day that we must get nearer pekin before the government there come to its sens the blockhead have go on negotiate with I just long enough to enable grant to bring all he army up to this point here we be then with we base establish in the heart of the country in a capital climate with abundance around we we army in excellent health and these stupid people give I a snub which oblige I to break with they no one know whether we progress be to be a fight or a ovation for in this country nothing can be foresee i think it better that the olive-branch should advance with the sword i be afraid that this change in the program -- a hostile instead of a peaceful march on pekin -- will keep I longer here because i can not send for frederick till peace be make and i can not i suppose leave pekin till he arrive there _ Sunday September 9th _ -- kweiliang and co want very much to call on I yesterday but i would not receive they the junior commissioner who be at canton with parke and know he well tell he that in fact the people here have be urge they to make a effort to prevent war say : ` if we be sure that the foreigner would have the best of it we should not care but if they be worst they will fall back on we and wreak they vengeance upon we ' this do not seem a very formidable state of mind as far as we be concern we have behave well to the people except at peytang and sinho and the consequence be that we can move through the country with comparative ease if the people try to cut off we baggage and refuse we supply we should find it very difficult to get on _ noon _ -- i have just return from a service on board the ` granada ' where the clergyman administer the sacrament to a small congregation at four we march to the war but as i go to bear the olive it be not so bad a Sunday 's work you may very likely hear through siberium of the result of we march before you receive this letter announce that it be to take place i shall not therefore speculate upon it _ yang-tsun about twenty mile above tientsin -- September 10th -- two pm _ -- this morning we start at about five and reach this encampment soon after seven a very nice ride cool and through a succession of crop of millet a stiff reedy stem some twelve or fourteen foot high with a tuft on the top be the physiognomy of the millet stalk it would puzzle the tartar cavalry to charge we through this crop as it be we have see no enemy and mr parke have induce the inhabitant to sell we a good many sheep and oxen we tent be not pitch till near noon so i sit during most of the forenoon under the shade of a hedge there have be thunder since and a considerable fall of rain i hope it will not make the road impassable but if it fill the river a little it will do we good for we may then use it for the transport of we supplies and it be now too low we do not know much what be ahead of we but we hear of tartar troops farther on and at tung-chow it be say that a large army be collect under sang-ko-lin-sin himself -lrb- they great general -rrb- i be now enjoy the life of a camp write to you seat on my portmanteau with my desk on my only chair it be perhaps better than my hothouse at tientsin -lrb- sidenote : new plenipotentiary -rrb- _ September 11th-six be _ -- parke and wade have just be in my tent with a letter from two new plenipotentiary -- really some of the highest personage in the empire -- state that they be under order to come to tientsin to settle everything and deprecate a forward movement -lrb- 2 -rrb- i shall of course stick by my program and decline to have anything to say to they till i reach tung-chow of course this proceeding on they part augur well for peace it pour all last evening and the general determine not to march this morning but as it be fine now i think we may start at noon and make out we allotted march it be cooler this morning and i think it not improbable that the thunder of yesterday may close the hot season however the sun be come out in he strength so one can not say what the day may bring forth _ ten _ be -- all we cart-driver with they animal disappear during last night leave the cart behind they probably they get a hint from the chinese authority i be sorry for it for if we begin to resort to measure of violence to supply ourselves we may entirely alter the footing on which we have hitherto stand with the people we be put all we surplus goods into junk in order to reduce we baggage -lrb- sidenote : chinese gentleman-farmer -rrb- _ nan-tsai-tsun -- September 12th _ -- where will this letter be send from it be begin at a small town on the close of we march of to-day which ought to have be we march of yesterday it be a very mild one -- about eight mile -- through a nice country more wooded than former march and with bright sunshine and a fresh almost frosty air the sunshine we have not at first for we start before the sun have appear on the horizon instead of trust to we tent we have this day take up we abode in the house of a chinese gentleman - farmer the owner of about 1000 acre it be nearly as large as the house i occupy at tientsin at least it have nearly as many court the gentleman have a good library in which i have establish myself and he seem poor man very anxious to accommodate we though he appearance be not that of a man entirely at he ease as i be start this morning i get a second letter from the new plenipotentiary rather more defiant in its tone and say that there be troops at we next station with whom we shall come into collision if we advance with a army parke be go on with a escort and we shall soon know from he what the state of the case really be -lrb- sidenote : ho-see-woo -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : monastery -rrb- _ ho-see-woo -- September 14th _ -- we have a charming march to this place yesterday morning the country much more beautiful than before and hill in the distance all around we the most luxuriant crop and hamlet embosome in clump of willow the temperature be delicious almost too cold at start but later a fresh breeze in we face give the requisite coolness and no more we march be about twelve mile and on reach its close i be conduct to a temple where i now be it be a monastery with very nice apartment and quantity of stable grain agricultural implement & c all indicative of a very prosperous community i have see no _ bonzerie _ on anything like so comfortable a scale i have a second letter from my commissioner in the evening of the last day on which i write a page of this journal more humble in its tone then the precede one and as my general be get uneasy about he supplies & c i think it necessary to make a kind of proposition for a arrangement we soldier do so little for themselves and they necessity be so great that we move but slowly we present party consist of about 1500 fight man but we count about 4000 mouth and all must have abundantly of the best the french -lrb- i admit that they take more out of the country and sometimes perhaps by rougher method -rrb- carry on they back several day ' provision they work in all sort of way for the army the contrast be i must say very striking i therefore think it better to send wade and parke to the new imperial commissioner to see whether they intend to resist or not and to make a proposal to test this they set out last night and i have just hear from they that as they do not find the commissioner at the place they expect -lrb- matow -rrb- they be go on to tung-chow the place where i intend to sign the convention parke be one of the most remarkable man i ever meet for energy courage and ability combined i do not know where i could find he match and this join to a facility of speak chinese which he share only with lay make he at present _ the _ man of the situation -lrb- sidenote : term agree to -rrb- after eight hour ' discussion the chinese commissioner concede every point agree among other thing that the army should advance to a place call five-li point within six mile of tung-chow and there remain while the ambassador proceed with a escort of 1000 man to pekin in the high character and standing of the two commissioner one the minister of war the other a prince of the blood imperial and in they repeat assurance that ` what they sign be as though the emperor sign it ' and that ` no comparison could be draw between the authority vest in they and that hold ' by previous commissioner there appear to be everything necessary to justify the belief that they word might be trust unhappily the confidence which the ally be thus lead to repose in they be destine to be deceive not however so far as appear owe to bad faith on they part but owe to the fact that they pacific influence at court be overborne on this occasion by that of the war party head by the commander-in-chief sang-ko-lin-sin -lrb- 3 -rrb- on the return of the two secretary from the conference lord elgin at once acquaint baron gro and sir hope grant with its result and it be agree that the commanders-in-chief should move forward on Monday the 17th from ho-se-woo to the place already mention five-li point which they expect to reach in two day ' march and that at the same time or rather before the departure of the army mr parke and some member of the ambassador 's suite should proceed to tung-chow to prepare for he reception and to procure means of transport accompany by a officer of the quarter-master general 's department and another of the commissariat and escort by a small body of troops -lrb- 4 -rrb- _ Sunday September 16th _ -- we have have service in my temple the general and staff attend wade and parke do good work at tung - chow it be arrange now that the general and bulk of the force proceed to-morrow on they way to the point at which -lrb- if the chinese plenipotentiary come in to all we term -rrb- we be to stay the progress of the main body go on from that point with a escort of 1000 man this place be about five mile from tung-chow and twenty from pekin and so i hope to effect my pacific entry into pekin this place have be i be sorry to say much maltreat for the people run away and when that take place it be impossible to prevent plunder the present plan be that i remain here till the army have take up its new position and all be arrange for my reception at pekin and tung-chow when i shall move on gro be here he have just be with I and be in a great state because we soldier in they zeal to drive away all chinese robber have drive away all he coolie _ September 17th _ -- i ride out very early this morning to see my general before he start and to give he a hint about the _ looting _ which have be bad here he disapprove of it as much as i do parke go off again this morning to tung-chow with another missive from I to my prince -lrb- the new plenipotentiary -rrb- rather stiff and plain-spoken and loch be go with he to get cart & c as i have no means of convey my goods and chattel i shall probably hear to - morrow whether there be any hitch but even if all be right i hardly expect to get on before Thursday for want of transport -lrb- sidenote : agreement break -rrb- _ September 18th -- noon _ -- there be firing in front of we and i have a letter from parke from tung-chow state that the prince and he colleague make great difficulty about a _ audience _ with the emperor if i be sure that parke and co be well out of tung-chow and that we should push on well i should not regret the firing _ five pm _ -- m de bastard gro ' secretary have just return from tung-chow he report that the tartar this morning be in know not what fear be -rrb- ride back to tung-chow to tell the prince & c of the position of the tartar army and that they should be hold responsible for the consequence loch be with the general i wonder he be not come to inform I of what have happen -lrb- sidenote : treacherous seizure of mr parke and other -rrb- at the time when these word be write nearly the whole of the party which have ride forth the morning before ` in high spirit at the prospect of a early and successful termination of the war ' have be treacherously seize by the soldier of sang-ko-lin-sin and mr parke and mr loch be be violently hurry off with they hand tie behind they back in a rude springless cart over a badly-paved road to the prison of pekin the detail of they capture and imprisonment together with such particulars as could afterwards be ascertain of they companion ' fate may be read in the very interesting narrative of one of the victim -lrb- 5 -rrb- we can here touch only upon those point in which they story be mix up with public event -lrb- sidenote : cause of the change -rrb- as to the origin and cause of the renewal of hostility it be impossible to speak with certainty nor be it probable that we shall ever arrive at a better opinion on the subject than that which be form by lord elgin on the spot in he report to the government he write : -- to hazard conjecture as to the motive by which chinese functionary be actuate be not a very safe undertaking and it be very possible that further information may modify the view which i now entertain on this point i be however dispose at present to doubt there have be a deliberate intention of treachery on the part of prince tsaus and he colleague but i apprehend that the general-in-chief sang-ko - lin-sin think that they have compromise he military position by allow we army to establish itself so near he line at chang-kium - wan he seek to counteract the evil effect of this by make a great swagger of parade and preparation to resist when the ally army approach the camping-ground allot to they several of we people colonel walker with he escort my private secretary mr loch baron gro ' secretary of embassy comte de bastard and other pass through the tartar army during the course of the morning on they way from tung-chow without encounter any rudeness or ill-treatment whatsoever at about a quarter to ten however a french commissariat officer be assault by some tartar soldier under circumstance which be not very clearly ascertain and this incident give rise to a engagement which soon become general on the whole i come to the conclusion that in the proceedings of the chinese plenipotentiary and commander-in-chief in this instance there be that mixture of stupidity want of straightforwardness suspicion and bluster which characterise so generally the conduct of affair in this country but i can not believe that after the experience which sang-ko-lin-sin have already have of we superiority in the field either he or he civil colleague could have intend to bring on a conflict in which as the event have prove he be so sure to be worst -lrb- sidenote : firm measure -rrb- late on the night of the 18th lord elgin receive at the same time the report of a successful engagement and the intelligence of the capture of he friend from this moment he feel that until the prisoner be give up there could be no further negotiation a notification be at once issue that ` all english and french subject be require to return to the head-quarter of they respective army and that if any impediment be put in the way of they return the city of pekin would forthwith be attack and take ' even when offer come that they should be restore on condition of he withdraw he troops he refuse to listen to such term convince that any sign of yield on he part would be as dangerous to they safety as it would be fatal to all hope of success in the object of he mission -lrb- 6 -rrb- _ September 23rd _ -- i have have a very busy time since i last write in this journal i have moreover be separate from it and from all my effect on the 21st we have another battle with the tartar i accompany the army and see it all consider that the tartar be so wretchedly armed and lead they do pretty well we be now about six mile from pekin but i believe the general will not move for a week we learn that parke and he companion viz loch de norman bowlby captain brabazon lieutenant anderson nineteen sikh and one of the dragoon guard be in pekin but we have have no communication with they yet -lrb- sidenote : pali-chiao -rrb- _ pali-chiao -- September 27th _ -- i close my last letter somewhat in haste for i have be separate for three day from it and my desk and when we meet again i be busy with my despatch & c the arrest of parke and the other be a very disagreeable incident and we do not yet know what it may lead to i send word yesterday to the emperor 's brother who be now name to treat with I that unless they be return to the camp within three day ' time and a pledge be give that the convention i draw up at tientsin be sign pekin will be assault we be anxious until we receive a answer to this _ ultimatum _ it be a reply to a letter from the prince to I in which he coolly state that the prisoner should be return when we army and fleet have retire from the country meantime we have a army in excellent health abundantly supply and which in five action with the enemy have lose some twenty kill i think i tell you at the close of my last letter that at midnight on the 18th i receive a note in pencil from the general tell I what have lead to the conflict of that day at 330 be i send a answer by crealock and at five set off with a escort of thirty irregular to ride about twenty mile to the general 's camp we then where we now be among some tree we sleep in tent but we have a house where we mess i be live with the general as my establishment have not yet be bring up from ho - see-woo i ride over yesterday to see the russian minister who with he sixteen cossack be occupy the village or rather town of chin-kia-wan which be take after the affair of the 18th it be a sad scene of desolation general ignatieff be very obliging and friendly as i have indeed find he to be throughout he and i entirely agree as to how the chinese should be fight i may be very near the close of this china business or i may be at the commencement of a new series of difficulty all be very uncertain at present the climate be pleasant here be it not for the quantity of dust which be overwhelming we have abundance of grape and some other good fruit _ September 29th _ -- at midnight of the 27th i be rouse by wade who bring I a letter from prince kung -lrb- the emperor 's brother -rrb- a good deal milder than the last but still imply that parke & c be not to be return until the treaty & c be sign the comparative mildness of the tone of this communication be clearly attributable to the firmness of my last letter and i therefore induce those with whom i act to agree to nay adhering to it in my reply i accordingly write to say that the army would advance unless the prisoner should return in the course of to-day but that i do not intend to add to the convention which i have already furnish to the chinese plenipotentiary and that i will sign that at once and close the war if they choose i hardly expect to see we friend to-day the general will not advance to-morrow but they say they will on Monday meanwhile it be rain a sort of english rain not tropical and if we have not too much of it it will do good _ October 1st _ -- yesterday morning come another letter propose that the army should retire to chin-kia-wan and that then the treaty should be sign and the prisoner restore this be clearly inadmissible as the chinese would infer from it that whenever they have a difficulty with we they have only to kidnap some of we people to bring we to term so we have again hand the matter over to the general from whose hand indeed it would not now have be take if they have not urge I to make this last overture to prince kung i do not know when they will advance _ October 3rd _ -- we have move about two mile and be now lodge in a mosque -- a nice building a good deal ornament -- which be for the nonce turn to profane use the army be to have advance to attack sang-ko-lin-sin 's force to-morrow but now i be kung sign by loch and parke loch manage in he signature to convey to we in hindostanee that the letter be write under compulsion as it be in chinese the information be hardly necessary it say that _ they two _ be well treat complimented prince kung and ask for some clothes we have hear nothing about the other who be miss -lrb- sidenote : advance on pekin -rrb- _ October 5th _ -- we leave we mosque this morning at about seven the whole army be draw up in contiguous column of regiment and have a good appearance the cavalry on the right then the artillery and then the infantry the french be on we leave in this way we advance about four mile when we reach a place from which we see one of the gate of pekin at about a mile and a half distance we meet with no enemy but we hear of he about three mile farther on however the french decline to go any farther so here we remain for the night and we have get into a joss-house which be lucky for we have no tent with we -- only a very light kit and three day ' provision for each person we hear that the emperor have leave for tartary which be very probable we might have stop he if we have march on immediately after the 21st ultimo but that be in the judgment of the general impossible -lrb- sidenote : suburb -rrb- _ October 6th -- five pm _ -- we be lodge in a _ lamaserie _ in the north-west suburb of pekin we move begin at seven we stream along narrow road in a long line i get a scolding from the general for outflank the skirmisher which i do to get out of the dust at about nine we reach a brick-kiln from whence we have a view of pekin and of a mound behind which as we be assure sang-ko-lin - sin and he army be encamp we halt for some time and then advance we on the right the french on the left towards these suppose camp the french be to attack in front we be to take the enemy in flank i be with the second division of we force when we arrive abreast of the entrenchment we could see nothing of a enemy after a while i ride to the hear of yet and we can not discover what have become of the french it be a nice country cover with clump of tree and suburban villa the temperature of the air be cool but the sun be very hot all day -lrb- sidenote : the summer palace -rrb- _ Sunday October 7th _ -- we hear this morning that the french and we cavalry have capture the summer palace of the emperor all the big - wig have flee nothing remain but a portion of the household we be tell that the _ prisoner _ be all in pekin _ five pm _ -- i have just return from the summer palace it be really a fine thing like a english park -- numberless building with handsome room and fill with chinese _ curio _ and handsome clock bronze & c but alas such a scene of desolation the french general come up full of protestation he have prevent _ looting _ in order that all the plunder might be divide between the army & c & c there be not a room that i saw in which half the thing have not be take away or break to piece i try to get a regiment of ours send to guard the place and then sell the thing by auction but it be difficult to get thing do by system in such a case so some officer be leave who be to fill two or three cart with treasure which be to be sell plunder and devastate a place like this be bad enough but what be much worse be the waste and breakage out of 1000000 _ l _ worth of property i daresay 50000 _ l _ will not be realize french soldier be destroy in every way the most beautiful silk break the jade ornament and porcelain & c war be a hateful business the more one see of it the more one detest it -lrb- sidenote : return of some of the captive -rrb- press thus closely up to the wall of the capital the chinese regent -- for the emperor have retire to tartary ` be oblige by law to hunt in the autumn ' -- yield at last to save the storm of the city in the afternoon of the 8th of October the english and french prisoner detain in pekin numbering eight in all be send into the camp -lrb- 7 -rrb- _ October 9th _ -- yesterday at 4 pm parke loch and one of fane 's irregular arrive with they be four french soldier and m d'escayrac -lrb- the head of a scientific commission -rrb- the hand and wrist of the latter be in a sad condition they have be so hurt by the cord tie round they bowlby de norman and the rest do not seem to be in pekin as we have hope parke and loch be very badly treat for the first ten day since then conciliation have be the order of the day and i have no doubt because i stand firm if i have waver they would have be lose because the chinese finding they have a lever with which they could move we would have use they advantage unsparingly parke and loch have behave very well under circumstance of great danger the narrative of they adventure be very interesting but i can not attempt to give it in this letter they seem to be in good health notwithstanding the hardship they have go through in a public despatch of the same date announce the restoration of the captive he write : - to no one of they numerous friend be the return of these gentleman a matter of more heartfelt gratification than it be to I since the period of they arrest i have be compel by a sense of duty to turn a deaf ear to every overture for they restoration which have involve the slightest retrograde movement of we army or the abandonment of any demand previously prefer by I against the chinese government i have feel that any such concession on my part would have establish a most fatal precedent because it would have lead the chinese to suppose that by kidnapping englishman they might effect object which they be unable to achieve by fair fighting or diplomacy i confess that i have be moreover throughout of opinion that in adopt this uncompromising tone and boldly set the national above the personal interest i be in point of fact best consult the welfare of we friend who be in durance but it be not to be expect that all person would view in the same light a question of policy so obscure and apart from the warm personal interest which i feel in they safety you lordship can well understand that it relieve I from a great load of anxiety to learn from the result that the course which i have follow be not ill - calculate to promote it -lrb- 8 -rrb- later in the same despatch he express himself anxiously yet hopefully about the captive who be still miss : -- it be a matter of great concern to I that we know as yet nothing certain respect the fate of mr bruce 's attaché mr de norman mr bowlby the special correspondent of the _ time _ and the nineteen trooper -lrb- sense which i entertain which the british army entertain -- and on this point i may appeal to my gallant friend who be present here this evening and who conduct that army triumphantly to pekin with so have pass unpunished would have place in jeopardy the life of every european in china i feel that the time have come when i must choose between the indulgence of a not unnatural sensibility and the performance of a painful duty the alternative be not a pleasant one but i trust that there be no man serve the crown in a responsible position who would hesitate when it be present to he as to the decision at which he should arrive -lrb- 2 -rrb- and now sir to pass to another topic i have be repeatedly ask whether in my opinion the interest of art in this country be likely to be in any degree promote by the open up of china i must say in reply that i do not think that in matter of art we have much to learn from that country but i be not quite prepared to admit that even in this department we can gain nothing from they the distinguish characteristic of the chinese mind be this -- that at all point of the circle describe by man 's intelligence it seem occasionally to have catch glimpse of a heaven far beyond the range of its ordinary ken and vision it catch a glimpse of the path which lead to military supremacy when it invent gunpowder some century before the discovery be make by any other nation it catch a glimpse of the path which lead to maritime supremacy when it make at a period equally remote the discovery of the mariner 's compass it catch a glimpse of the path which lead to literary supremacy when in the tenth century it invent the printing press and as my illustrious friend on my right -lrb- sir e landseer -rrb- have remind I it have catch from time to time glimpse of the beautiful in color and design but in the hand of the chinese themselves the invention of gunpowder have explode in cracker and harmless firework the mariner 's compass have produce nothing better than the coast junk the art of printing have stagnate in stereotyped edition of _ confucius _ and the most cynical representation of the grotesque have be the principal product of chinese conception of the sublime and beautiful nevertheless i be dispose to believe that under this mass of abortion and rubbish there lie hide some spark of a diviner fire which the genius of my countryman may gather and nurse into a flame -lrb- sidenote : dinner at the mansion house -rrb- a few day afterwards at a dinner give at the mansion house in he honor he be again greet with more than lady elgin who with he youngest daughter lady louisa bruce reach calcutta on the 8th of January 1863 -lrb- sidenote : state of indium -rrb- in pass from the personal narrative of these month to they public history it be necessary to bear in mind what be the state of the indian empire at the moment when lord elgin undertake its government -lrb- sidenote : peace -rrb- ` indium ' to use he own word ` be at peace at peace in a sense of the term more emphatic and comprehensive than it have ever before bear in indium the occurrence which have take place during the period of lord dalhousie 's government have establish the prestige of the british arm as against external foe lord canning 's vice-royalty have teach the same lesson to domestic enemy no military operation of magnitude be in progress to call for prompt and vigorous action on the part of the ruling authority or to furnish matter for narration of thrilling interest on the contrary a hearty acquiescence in the belief that no such opportunity exist and that it be incumbent upon he by all practicable means to prevent they recurrence be the first duty which the situation of affair prescribe to a new governor-general ' -lrb- sidenote : question to be solve -rrb- there be indeed grave question await solution question of great perplexity and embarrassment though of a domestic and peaceful character some of they the more perplexing because they bear upon ` those jealousy of race which be the source of almost all we difficulty in indium ' but as regard such question he habitual caution as well as the philosophic turn of he mind lead he to study very carefully all the condition of each problem before attempt to propound any solution of he own and in the meantime he feel that he duty be to employ any personal influence which he could acquire in smooth the course of such measure as have be set in operation by the authority of other ` the first virtue ' he say to one of he colleague ` which you and i have to practice here at present be self-denial we must for a time at least walk in path trace out by other ' but though for the reason above state it would be a mistake to look in the record of the time for any great measure executive or administrative on which he have set he mark he various speech and letter more especially the full and frank communication which he address from time to time to the secretary of state for indium sir charle wood show with what keenness of interest as well as with what sagacity he approach the study of indian question a few extract from he correspondence be here give to illustrate this and as afford some indication of the unremitting industry with which he labor at this period search into and mature he view upon one difficult subject after another as well as the whole plan of indian government _ to sir charle wood _ calcutta April 9th 1862 -lrb- sidenote : the army -rrb- now for the army i must observe in the first place that in the reasoning employ here in favor of the maintenance of a large army native and european there be a good deal that be circular and puzzling to a beginner when i ask why so considerable a native army be require i be tell that the native must bear a certain proportion to the european force that european can not undertake cantonment duty or speak generally any of the duty which the military may from time to time be call to render in support of the civil power during peace that in war again they be admirable on the battle-field but that they can not turn they victory to account by follow up a discomfited foe unless they have the aid of native troops nor perform many other service which be not less indispensable than great battle to success against a enemy who know the ground and be inure to the climate this line of argument very naturally raise the question wherefore then be the maintenance of so large a european army necessary rebellion have be crush and european troops be not suit for the repression of such local disturbance as occasionally occur there be little present prospect of war from without though persium be move towards herat and apparently prepare for dost mohammed 's death the answer which i invariably receive be this -- ` you can not tell what will happen in indium heretofore you have hold the sikh in subjection by the aid of the sepoy and the sepoy by means of the sikh but see what be happen now the sikh soldier be quarter all over indium they be fraternise with the native of the south -- adopt they custom and even they faith half the soldier in a regiment lately station at benare be convert to hindooism before they leave that holy place beware or you will shortly have to cope in indium with a hostile combination more formidable than any of those which you have encounter before ' if you draw from all this the inference that what you really dread be you native army you get into the vicious circle again do not suppose that i be tempt by these logical paradox to run to hasty conclusion i be aware that for many reason we must now entertain and probably shall long find it necessary to entertain a large army native and european in indium practically what we have to do be to endeavor by a judicious system of recruit organization and distribution to render we army as serviceable and as little a source of peril as may be but i do think that they go far to prove that notwithstanding we vast physical superiority to anything which can be bring against we we should find it a difficult task to maintain we authority in indium by the sword alone and that they justify a very jealous scrutiny of all scheme of expenditure for military object which render necessary the imposition or maintenance of tax which occasion general discontent or deprive the government of the fund requisite for carry on work of improvement that have the double advantage of stimulate the growth of wealth in the country and increase the efficiency of the means of self-defence which we possess \* \* \* \* \* _ to a friend in scotland interested in the cultivation of cotton _ calcutta may 21st 1862 -lrb- sidenote : cultivation of cotton -rrb- i beg to assure you that i do not yield to yourself in my desire to promote the extension of cotton cultivation in indium and above all improvement in the quality of the staple i consider that the interest of indium be involve in this improvement to a greater degree even than those of great britain for no doubt if the quality of the indian product be so far raise as to admit of its compete on term approach to equality with that of america it would obtain a permanent footing in the great market to which it have access now only at moment of extraordinary dearth moreover i do not scruple to confess to you that i be not so bigoted in my adhesion to the dogma of political economy as to be unwilling at a season of crisis like the present to entertain proposal for accelerate this result merely because they contravene the principle of that science on the contrary i receive thankfully suggestion for accomplish a object which i have so much at heart more especially when they emanate from person deeply interested and thoroughly conversant with the subject like yourself -- even when they fall within the category of what you style ` extraordinary measure ' but you will surely allow that the _ onus probandus _ lie very heavily on a government which adopt measure of this class and that if by abnormal interference it check the natural and healthy operation of the law of demand on capitalist and cultivator it incur a weighty responsibility even as regard the specific recommendation which you have make and which have much to justify it in my eye -- because i would go great length in the direction of aid the ryot to improve they staple if i could see my way to effect this object without do more harm than good -- i must observe that there be question which have to be very gravely and carefully examine before it can be act upon in the first place it be right that i should tell you that the opinion which obtain here respect the result of recent operation in dharwar in so far as the case furnish a precedent for the interference of government officer in such matter differ widely from that entertain by you but set this point aside and assume for the sake of argument that the interposition at dharwar be attend by unmixed benefit to all concerned do it follow that corresponding success would accompany the mission of fifty military officer to the cotton district of indium for the purpose of induce the ryot to substitute exotic for native cotton in they cultivation in order to do this exotic cotton justice it must be treat with some care especially at the time of its introduction into district where it have widely from that of many part of indium where the season be divide between a deluge of rain and a period of bake heat be i likely to find fifty young military officer who would be competent to advise the ryot on point of so much delicacy and if the ryot follow they counsel be disappoint in the expectation which they have be lead to form what would be the effect on the prospects of cotton the interest of cotton cultivation in indium which the government can adopt without abandon its proper sphere of action not only without danger but with a high probability perhaps i might say a certainty of benefit to the great cause which we have in hand we can facilitate the establishment in indium of european cultivator and landholder who be the natural and legitimate adviser of the length but the importance of the subject and my respect for you opinion be my excuse \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ calcutta may 9th 1862 -lrb- sidenote : oriental not satisfy with show of this country -- the extreme difficulty of administer equal justice between native and european \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ July 16th 1862 -lrb- sidenote : against interference in afghanistan suggest itself as to whether the receive notion respect the relation which canning seek to establish between the native chief and the british government in indium be altogether correct or -lrb- as it principle : a doubt by no means unimportant now that this policy whatever it be be crown by the double aureole of success and death so that while on the one hand it be naturally set up as a example for imitation on the other we have not the author to refer to when difficulty arise respect its application -lrb- sidenote : -lrb- 1 -rrb- clemency -rrb- in approach the consideration of this very act as you be now act denounce I as you enemy and they friend and prove the sincerity of you belief by outrage and violence you will end by convince they that i be to be trust and i shall win the day guarantee for the accomplishment of this object in the first place it would be wholly unjustifiable for any one object however important to place such a strain upon we finances as this policy would involve in the second place however justifiable and necessary a system of government guarantee may be in certain circumstance it be essentially a expensive one because by secure to shareholder a minimum rate of interest on they capital it weaken in they the motive to economy and because by divide the responsibility for expenditure between government and railway official it diminish in the enterprise wholly unaided by the state but at any rate to private enterprise not protect by government guarantee but if so what be the condition which will entitle railway enterprise of this class to the countenance and encouragement of the government i lay it down as a fundamental principle that we ought to look to the eventual establishment of one uniform railway gauge for the whole of indium england have be compel to take the narrow gauge on its back and the whole capital expend upon the former may be say to have be throw away but what do this resolution in favor of a uniform gauge imply it will i think be admit that the main object of a uniform railway gauge be to enable the several railway line to exchange they plant in order to avoid transhipment of freight but if the plant of the subsidiary line be to be transport along the main line it must be sufficiently well finish to be fit to travel in safety at high speed and if the plant of the main line be to travel along the sir charle trevelyan _ camp jeyt : February 23 1863 -lrb- sidenote : supply of labor -rrb- no doubt there be a deficiency of labor in some part of indium and a excess in other moreover there be moral and physical obstacle which put difficulty in the way of the transfer of labor from place where it be redundant to those where it be want but to affirm generally of a country where labour-saving machine be in consequence of the cheapness of labor as little use as in indium that there be a ` want of labor ' seem to I to be a paradox i will give a example : -- if in america the climate make it necessary that every private white soldier should have a punkah pull over he day and night do you think that no agency but that of the human hand in its rudest and most direct application would be employ in this task and why be it otherwise in indium because labor be so cheap that necessity the mother of invention do not stimulate the ingenuity of man here as it do there far from deprecate the introduction of capital i should be delighted to hear that the amount to be spend in indium this year be to be three time what it promise to be i do not say to be spend by government for to this there be objection altogether irrespective of the question of the amount of labor available the first effect of this enlarged expenditure would no doubt be to raise the wages of labor this would be in itself a blessing for which i should thank god but its second and more permanent effect would be to increase the number of the class of skilled labourer which the patient sober and ingenious population of indium be fit to supply in so great abundance if due encouragement be give and further to drive capitalist to the substitution of machinery for brute human labor to a greater extent than be the practice now the ultimate result would therefore be to render the exist stock of labor doubly productive the fruit of this increase productiveness be divide in proportion more or less equitable between the labourer and capitalist i believe that the railway expenditure be already exercise a sensible influence of this salutary character body of navvy be become attach to the company who follow they from place to place and render they comparatively independent of the local supply of labor and above all by call forth native talent in the form of skilled labor they be impart that kind of education which will i believe do more for the elevation of the mass than any other which we can provide in indium \* \* \* \* \* _ to h s maine esq _ camp hodul : February 25 1863 -lrb- sidenote : special legislation -rrb- while i entirely concur in the opinion that the _ onus probandus _ rest and rest heavily too on the proposer of exceptional or particular legislation a assumption run through ------ 's letter to you which i be by no means prepare to admit he assume that in such matter as those with which we be now deal this _ particular legislation _ must be in the exclusive interest of the landlord and calculate to increase in he hand power which may be abused and the abuse of which be restrain by moral influence which operate less strongly where landlord and tenant be of different race than where they be homogeneous he cite strangely enough ireland where these moral influence which be of themselves generally sufficient in england and scotland be supplement by wholesale eviction on one side and murder on the other but the law of landlord and tenant be i believe the same in ireland as in england and it be quite possible that a little _ particular _ legislation which would have give either of the party the protection of positive law against injury which can now be redress only by a rude process of reprisal -lrb- one outrage balance another until the account be square -rrb- might have prove ultimately a benefit even to the party against which this particular legislation seem to be in the first instance direct the planter say we have a grievance attributable to special circumstance arise out of we relation with we ryot unless you give we a special remedy to meet we special grievance we fall back on we general power as landlord be we quite sure that in refuse the special remedy we be consult the interest of the weaker party viz the ryot of course this be all general there will remain the question : be there a grievance at all be it one which have any claim to a special remedy i quite agree that the _ onus _ of answer these question satisfactorily rest on the advocate of special legislation \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ roorkee : march 19 1863 -lrb- upon it \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ simlum : march 19 1863 -lrb- sidenote : financial credit -rrb- i be as desirous as you can be perhaps even more desirous to give no excuse for the charge of cooking account or make thing look pleasanter than they ought because i be quite confident that if we can keep the peace and show a unimpeachable balance-sheet we shall soon have more capital send limit will be put on the operation of the latter -lrb- sidenote : seat of government -rrb- as to the seat of government question i be strongly of opinion that the proper thing to do at present be to supreme government a more catholic character than it now possess and perhaps in some degree diminish the jealousy of calcutta influence which obtain so extensively i do not see my way towards contact with it for the present therefore i think that calcutta should continue to be the headquarters of government but that we should meet from time to time at other place for legislative purpose so likely to be i do not see why we should not legislate in camp if there be difficulty in provide house accommodation i should like if possible to hit upon a plan which would give we a sufficient range in choose and vary we place of meet more on all this hereafter \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ roorkee : march 19 1863 -lrb- sidenote : value of training at headquarters -rrb- i confess i think charle wood _ simlum : may 6 1863 in a general way i must say that i be incline to give a preference in dispose of these high office to person who have serve in the office of the supreme government or \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle wood _ simlum : may 21 1863 -lrb- sidenote : aristocracy -rrb- i have no objection _ primâ facie _ to a aristocracy and i be quite ready to admit that conflict claim of proprietorship in the same land be a evil but i also know that even in we old christian europe there be not many aristocracy that have have salt enough in they to prevent they from rot and when i consider what oriental society be when i reflect on the frightful corruption both of mind and body to which the inheritor of wealth and station be expose -- the general absence of motive to call forth good instinct or of restraint to keep bad in check -- i own that i do not feel quite sure that even if we could sweep away all rights of sub-proprietor or tenant and substitute for the complication incident to the present system a uniform land-tenure of great proprietor and tenant at will we should be much nearer the millennium than we be now -lrb- sidenote : against intermeddle in foreign politics -rrb- i be wholly oppose to that prurient intermeddle policy which find so much favor with certain class of indian official it be constantly thrust we into equivocal situation in which we act and we profession of respect for the independence of other nation be in contradiction and in which we proceedings become taint with the double reproach of inconsistency and selfishness nothing in my opinion can be more fatal to we prestige and legitimate influence my modest ambition for england be that she should in this eastern world establish the reputation of be all-just and all-powerful but to achieve this object we must cease to attempt to play a great part in small intrigue or to dictate in case where we have not positive interest which we can avow or conviction sufficiently distinct to enable we to speak plainly we must interfere only where we can put forward a unimpeachable plea of right or duty and when we announce a resolution we neighbor must understand that it be the decree of fate \* \* \* \* \* _ to sir charle trevelyan _ simlum : June 17 1863 -lrb- sidenote : council to meet at lahore -rrb- on the first occasion of transfer the council from calcutta to another place on we neighbor -lrb- sidenote : sitana fanatic -rrb- late in the month of September during the last day of lord elgin 's stay at simlum occur the only break in the otherwise peaceful tenor of he government in the shape of a outburst of certain wahabee fanatic inhabit a frontier district in the upper valley of the indus the outburst be not without historical interest as connect with similar disturbance which have assume more serious proportion but it be notice here chiefly as illustrate the view which lord elgin take of the policy and duty of the british government in such case it be not without the greatest reluctance that he be induce to take up the quarrel at all : for he have the strongest aversion for warlike operation in the exist state of indium and particularly on the frontier of afghanistan and he have no small distrust of those military tendency and that thirst for opportunity of distinction which be apt to characterise the ablest governor of frontier province but he have prevent a sitana expedition in the previous year he be assure that the recent inroad of the fanatic be the direct consequence of he last year 's supineness and he be tell that if he again hold back the disturbance would be renew another year with usury moreover he be assure that the project expedition would secure the peace of the frontier for a long period and that the operation would be little more than a military promenade and would be over before he camp reach peshawur it be scarcely possible for a civil governor to resist such a pressure of professional opinion and he consent to take measure of repression write to sir charle wood on the subject he say : -- the overt act charge consist in the return of the fanatic to sitana whence they be drive out by we some year ago and the frontier tribe in question be hold to be guilty because they have allow they to return to this place although bind by treaty with we to refuse to admit they on a review of all the circumstance and look to the well-known character and design of the sitana fanatic i come to the conclusion that the interest both of prudence and humanity would be best consult by level a speedy and decisive blow at this embryo conspiracy accordingly it be arrange that the punjâb government should at once take the necessary measure for expel the fanatic from judoon where they have congregate and then if circumstance permit proceed to destroy they place of refuge at mulka but it be well know that in indium to use lord elgin 's own expression ` rise official be instinctively in favor of a good row ' some of those around he be urgent that the expedition should be defer until the spring and should then be organise on a larger scale and with more comprehensive object lord elgin set he face decidedly against this i wish -lrb- he write -rrb- by a sudden and vigorous blow to check this trouble on we frontier while it be in a nascent condition the other plan would give it several month to fester and to extend itself and if there be among the mohammedan population in these region the disposition to combine against we which be allege and which be indeed the justification of the measure propose how far might not the root of the conspiracy stretch themselves in that time the afghan in they distract state might furnish sympathiser we should be invite to interfere in they internal affair in order to oppose those among they who be abet we mohammedan adversary in short there be no end to the complication in which this postponement of active operation might involve we everything be more or less uncertain in such affair but in the absence of any very palpable blunder what we actually propose to do would appear to be a pretty safe proceed the main purpose be to expel the fanatic from judoon and it be hardly possible that we should fail in this as they be within easy reach of we there the further object -- of punish other tribe and destroy the refuge of the fanatic at mulka -- may be abandon if it be deem advisable without any loss of prestige though of course with some abatement of the completeness of the movement i therefore think it necessary to adhere to my original resolution -lrb- sidenote : the himalaya -rrb- on the 26th of September lord elgin leave simla _ en route _ for sealkote where he be to rejoin he camp and proceed with it to peshawur the most distant station on the north-west frontier before make he way to the great _ rendezvous _ at lahore on the way to sealkote he be to traverse the upper valley of the bea the ravee and the chenab and the mountain that divide they he main object be to inspect the great tea plantation public and private recently set on foot in those part and to ascertain for himself what facility or possibility the country afford for commercial intercourse with ladâk and china for the first week he route lay nearly northwards through scene very similar to those which he have leave at simlum ` we be go through a beautiful country ' he write on the 4th of October ` and the people seem cheerful and well-to-do ' shortly afterwards have pass over the sutlej at komharsen he cross a considerable range of mountain by the jalourus pass and find himself in the fertile basin of the bea direct he course still northwards he follow this river up to its source among the hill and thence cross by the steep and high rotung pass from the valley of the bea into that of the chenab -- from the rich and smile country of kuloo into a rugged and inhospitable tract call lahoul he do not however remain long in these desolate region but after cross the twig bridge across the chandra a affluent of the chenab and inspect a wooden bridge which have just be construct to take its place he retrace he step southwards to sultanpore on the bea river from thence on the 18th of October he write as follow to sir charle wood : -- -lrb- sidenote : kuloo -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : rotung pass -rrb- -lrb- sidenote : twig bridge -rrb- thus far we sultanpore in kuloo at a elevation of about 4000 foot above the sea but a few day ago we -lrb- the man of the party -rrb- scale the rotung pass which divide kuloo from lahoul and attain in so do a height of 13000 foot with a temperature low in proportion this pass be on the road from these province to ladâk and china and i visit on the other side of it a new bridge over the chandra which will be a great convenience to trader hitherto if the trader use mule or other animal of this magnitude they could cross the river with they only by make they swim or if sheep be they beast of burden by complete in a few week this road however useful though it will doubtless be when improve lead through ladâk and the merchandise transport along it become subject to the exaction of the ruler of they own food make they own clothes not much give to exchange and extremely averse to labor i ask a manager of a tea plantation the other day how he be off for labor he say that he contrived to induce expect to find it both native and european be subject to fever at certain season especially in the valley but i have no doubt that the latter may do well as employer of labor this place -lrb- sultanpore -rrb- be only about 4000 foot above the level of the sea and i have little doubt that be the state of cultivation and trade to justify the outlay a cart road might be make to it without great difficulty from the plain this would greatly develop both its natural resource and its capability as a commercial route the state of the forest which we have encounter during we route have also wood at all we be now proceed towards the kangra valley where we expect to find tea plantation in a more advanced condition -lrb- sidenote : illness -rrb- in this letter and other of the same date subsidence of the mutiny could recognize in the well-planned and well-kept garden with its two graveyard and the beautiful central monument on its grassy mound the site of the horrid slaughter-house which then stand in blood - stain ruin about the well choke with the victim of the foulest treachery the world have ever see the ceremonial be as simple as it well could be and few ceremony could be more impressive the viceroy advance to the top of the step of the memorial and through the commissioner formally request the bishop to consecrate that spot and the adjacent burial-place the bishop take he place then head a procession of the clergy and the people present and proceed round the two burial-place and the interior of the memorial itself with music playing and soldier chant the 49th 115th 139th and 23rd psalm after this he chaplain read the form of consecration which be sign by the bishop and the 90th psalm have be sing he shortly address those present in most feeling manly and impressive term befitting the occasion and the ceremonial conclude with prayer read by the chaplain of the station closing with the benediction by the bishop ' the bishop be the lament george cotton
